questions.question_text: What are the two main branches of economics that study individual markets and economy-wide aggregates, respectively?

options.A: Applied economics and theoretical economics
options.B: Positive economics and normative economics
options.C: Microeconomics and macroeconomics
options.D: Classical economics and behavioral economics

questions.question_text: Which economic system is based on private ownership of the means of production, competitive markets, wage labor, and the profit motive?

options.A: Mercantilism
options.B: Feudalism
options.C: Socialism
options.D: Capitalism

questions.question_text: Which economic and political philosophy is characterised by social ownership of the means of production, as opposed to private ownership?

options.A: Neoliberalism
options.B: Socialism
options.C: Libertarianism
options.D: Capitalism

questions.question_text: Which international organization, established in 1995, serves as the main body regulating the rules of trade between nations and facilitating multilateral trade agreements?

options.A: The World Bank
options.B: The World Trade Organization (WTO)
options.C: The International Monetary Fund (IMF)
options.D: The United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD)

questions.question_text: What are the two main statistical measures of poverty that compare income against basic needs and against the living standards of others in the same society?

options.A: Primary poverty and secondary poverty
options.B: Absolute poverty and relative poverty
options.C: Structural poverty and cyclical poverty
options.D: Urban poverty and rural poverty

questions.question_text: Which widely used statistical measure, developed by Italian statistician Corrado Gini in 1912, quantifies income or wealth inequality on a scale from 0 (perfect equality) to 1 (perfect inequality)?

options.A: The Palma ratio
options.B: The Gini coefficient
options.C: The Human Development Index
options.D: The Lorenz curve

questions.question_text: What term describes the process of increasing interdependence and integration among the economies, markets, societies, and cultures of different countries worldwide?

options.A: Liberalization
options.B: Industrialization
options.C: Globalization
options.D: Urbanization

questions.question_text: Which Scottish economist and philosopher, often called the 'father of economics,' published An Inquiry into the Nature and Causes of the Wealth of Nations in 1776?

options.A: John Stuart Mill
options.B: Adam Smith
options.C: Thomas Malthus
options.D: David Ricardo

questions.question_text: What trade policy, the opposite of protectionism, does not restrict imports or exports through tariffs, quotas, or subsidies?

options.A: Free trade
options.B: Managed trade
options.C: Fair trade
options.D: Autarky

questions.question_text: According to economist Amartya Sen, how does economic development differ from economic growth?

options.A: Economic development applies only to wealthy nations, while economic growth applies to all nations
options.B: Economic development measures trade surpluses, while economic growth measures government spending
options.C: Economic development improves well-being and quality of life, while economic growth is only an increase in GDP
options.D: Economic development focuses on industrial output, while economic growth measures population increase

questions.question_text: Which country was the first in the world to enact a national minimum wage, passing the Industrial Conciliation and Arbitration Act in 1894?

options.A: United States
options.B: United Kingdom
options.C: New Zealand
options.D: Australia

questions.question_text: During the Great Depression, approximately what peak unemployment rate did the United States reach in 1933?

options.A: About 50%
options.B: About 35%
options.C: About 15%
options.D: About 25%

questions.question_text: Which French engineer published 'On the Measurement of the Utility of Public Works' in 1844, laying the groundwork for modern cost-benefit analysis?

options.A: Vilfredo Pareto
options.B: Alfred Marshall
options.C: Léon Walras
options.D: Jules Dupuit

questions.question_text: Which economist won the 2017 Nobel Prize in Economics for his contributions to behavioral economics, including the concept of 'nudge' theory?

options.A: Cass Sunstein
options.B: Robert Shiller
options.C: Richard Thaler
options.D: Daniel Kahneman

questions.question_text: In labor economics, what does the marginal productivity theory of wages predict about the relationship between a worker's pay and their output?

options.A: Workers are paid a wage equal to their marginal product of labor
options.B: Workers are paid based on seniority regardless of output
options.C: Workers are paid the average product of all employees
options.D: Workers are paid a fixed share of total firm revenue

questions.question_text: Who coined the term 'econometrics' in 1926 and co-founded the Econometric Society, later sharing the first Nobel Prize in Economics in 1969?

options.A: Jan Tinbergen
options.B: Lawrence Klein
options.C: Trygve Haavelmo
options.D: Ragnar Frisch

questions.question_text: In Keynesian economics, what is the 'paradox of thrift'?

options.A: When wages increase, employment rises rather than falls
options.B: When everyone saves more individually, aggregate demand falls, potentially reducing total savings economy-wide
options.C: When governments cut spending, tax revenues unexpectedly increase
options.D: When interest rates rise, consumers borrow more instead of less

questions.question_text: What type of trade barrier sets a government-imposed physical limit on the quantity of a specific good that may be imported during a given period?

options.A: An export subsidy
options.B: An import quota
options.C: A voluntary export restraint
options.D: A tariff

questions.question_text: Which economist's 1964 book 'Human Capital' systematically analyzed education and training as economic investments, earning him the 1992 Nobel Prize?

options.A: Milton Friedman
options.B: Jacob Mincer
options.C: Theodore Schultz
options.D: Gary Becker

questions.question_text: The Gini coefficient is derived from the Lorenz curve. What does a Gini coefficient of 0 represent?

options.A: Perfect equality, where everyone has the same income
options.B: Perfect inequality, where one person holds all income
options.C: An economy with zero GDP growth
options.D: A population with zero tax burden

questions.question_text: Which school of economic thought, flourishing in Britain in the late 18th and early 19th centuries, held that market economies are largely self-regulating systems governed by natural laws of production and exchange?

options.A: Classical economics, developed by Adam Smith, David Ricardo, and John Stuart Mill
options.B: Neoclassical economics, developed by Alfred Marshall and Leon Walras
options.C: Mercantilist economics, developed by Thomas Mun and Jean-Baptiste Colbert
options.D: Keynesian economics, developed by John Maynard Keynes and his Cambridge followers

questions.question_text: In Kahneman and Tversky's prospect theory (1979), what key feature of the value function explains why the pain of losing $100 is felt more intensely than the pleasure of gaining $100?

options.A: Loss aversion, meaning the value function is steeper for losses than for gains
options.B: The certainty effect, meaning people prefer guaranteed outcomes over probabilistic ones
options.C: Probability weighting, meaning people overestimate the likelihood of rare events
options.D: Diminishing sensitivity, meaning each additional dollar of gain matters less

questions.question_text: In environmental economics, what type of tax is specifically designed to correct a negative externality, such as pollution, by making producers pay the marginal social cost of their activity?

options.A: A progressive income tax scaled to the polluter's revenue
options.B: A Pigouvian tax, named after economist Arthur Pigou
options.C: A Tobin tax levied on international financial transactions
options.D: A value-added tax levied on each stage of production

questions.question_text: The term 'regression' in regression analysis was coined by Sir Francis Galton in the 1880s. What biological phenomenon was he originally describing when he introduced this concept?

options.A: Natural selection, where organisms with favorable traits survive and reproduce at higher rates
options.B: Hereditary divergence, where successive generations grow progressively taller than the previous one
options.C: Regression toward the mean, where sons' heights tend to revert toward the population average rather than matching their fathers'
options.D: Genetic mutation, where offspring develop entirely new traits not present in their parents

questions.question_text: The terms of trade (TOT) is defined as the ratio of a country's export prices to its import prices. According to the Prebisch-Singer hypothesis, what long-run trend affects primary-commodity exporters?

options.A: Primary commodity prices rise faster than manufactured goods prices due to increasing scarcity of natural resources
options.B: Export and import prices converge to equality over time, eliminating all gains from trade
options.C: Primary commodity prices decline relative to manufactured goods prices, deteriorating their terms of trade over time
options.D: Manufactured goods exporters face declining terms of trade due to rising industrial competition

questions.question_text: What type of economic system combines elements of both capitalism and socialism, featuring private enterprise alongside government intervention such as regulation, public services, and welfare programs?

options.A: A laissez-faire economy
options.B: A mixed economy
options.C: A traditional economy
options.D: A command economy

questions.question_text: Which heterodox school of economics, founded by Thorstein Veblen, John R. Commons, and Wesley Clair Mitchell, emphasizes how laws, norms, and organizations shape economic behavior rather than assuming rational equilibrium?

options.A: Post-Keynesian economics
options.B: Chicago school economics
options.C: Austrian economics
options.D: Institutional economics

questions.question_text: Kenneth Arrow's seminal 1963 paper 'Uncertainty and the Welfare Economics of Medical Care' is considered foundational to health economics. What key argument did Arrow make about healthcare markets?

options.A: Government provision of healthcare is always more efficient than private markets due to economies of scale
options.B: Healthcare markets deviate from the competitive ideal due to uncertainty and information asymmetry between providers and patients
options.C: Healthcare should be treated as a luxury good whose consumption rises proportionally with income
options.D: Healthcare markets function efficiently because patients can freely choose among competing providers

questions.question_text: James Buchanan received the 1986 Nobel Prize in Economics for his work on public choice theory, developed with Gordon Tullock in their 1962 book. What is the central premise of public choice theory?

options.A: Markets fail so frequently that government intervention is almost always welfare-improving
options.B: Government officials always act in the public interest because democratic elections ensure accountability
options.C: Collective decisions reflect the preferences of the median voter without any distortion or rent-seeking
options.D: Political actors, like economic agents, are motivated by self-interest, so economic tools can analyze political decision-making

questions.question_text: Vernon Smith shared the 2002 Nobel Prize in Economics for establishing laboratory experiments as a tool in empirical economic analysis. What did his early market experiments demonstrate about competitive equilibrium theory?

options.A: Markets with even a small number of traders converge to competitive equilibrium prices predicted by theory
options.B: Laboratory markets always produce monopoly outcomes regardless of the number of participants
options.C: Experimental subjects consistently fail to reach any stable price, disproving equilibrium theory
options.D: Only markets with perfect information and infinitely many traders can reach competitive equilibrium

questions.question_text: In the Heckscher-Ohlin model of international trade, what primary factor determines a country's pattern of comparative advantage and export specialization?

options.A: Its level of technological innovation relative to trading partners
options.B: The geographic distance between it and its major trading partners
options.C: Its relative abundance of factors of production such as labor, capital, and land
options.D: The absolute size of its gross domestic product

questions.question_text: In econometrics, what two conditions must an instrumental variable satisfy to be considered valid for addressing endogeneity?

options.A: Relevance (correlated with the endogenous variable) and exogeneity (uncorrelated with the error term)
options.B: Sufficiency (captures all sample information) and completeness (identifies all parameters)
options.C: Stationarity (constant mean over time) and ergodicity (time averages equal ensemble averages)
options.D: Normality (normally distributed) and homoscedasticity (constant variance)

questions.question_text: The Lorenz curve, developed by Max O. Lorenz in 1905, plots the cumulative share of income against the cumulative share of the population. What does the diagonal 45-degree line on this graph represent?

options.A: Perfect equality, where every percentile of the population earns the same share of income
options.B: The median income level across the entire population
options.C: The average tax rate applied to each income bracket
options.D: Perfect inequality, where one person holds all the income

questions.question_text: The Stolper-Samuelson theorem (1941) predicts that a rise in the relative price of a good will have what effect on factor returns?

options.A: It lowers the real return to the factor used most intensively while raising returns to the scarce factor
options.B: It raises the real return to the factor used most intensively in that good's production and lowers the return to the other factor
options.C: It has no effect on factor returns because wages and rents adjust to maintain equilibrium
options.D: It raises real returns to all factors of production proportionally to the price increase

questions.question_text: The Austrian School of economics, founded by Carl Menger in 1871, is distinguished by its strict adherence to which methodological principle?

options.A: Logical positivism, requiring all economic claims to be empirically falsifiable
options.B: Methodological individualism, holding that social phenomena arise from individual motivations and actions
options.C: Methodological holism, analyzing economies as irreducible aggregate systems
options.D: Historical materialism, grounding economic analysis in class relations and modes of production

questions.question_text: The revealed comparative advantage (RCA) index, introduced by Béla Balassa in 1965, measures a country's export specialization. What does an RCA value greater than 1 indicate?

options.A: The country's tariff rate on that product is above the global median
options.B: The country has a comparative advantage in that product, exporting more than its expected world share
options.C: The country imports more of that product than it exports
options.D: The country's production costs for that product exceed the world average

questions.question_text: Contingent valuation is a survey-based technique used in environmental economics. What does it primarily ask respondents to estimate?

options.A: The market price they would charge to sell a natural resource on the open market
options.B: Their willingness to pay for preserving or improving a non-market good such as biodiversity or clean air
options.C: The amount of tax revenue governments should allocate to environmental regulation
options.D: The replacement cost of damaged infrastructure after a natural disaster

questions.question_text: The difference-in-differences (DiD) method estimates causal effects by comparing changes over time between a treatment group and a control group. What key assumption must hold for DiD estimates to be valid?

options.A: The parallel trends assumption: absent treatment, both groups would have followed the same trajectory over time
options.B: The stationarity assumption: the outcome variable must have a constant mean and variance across all time periods
options.C: The independence assumption: treatment and control groups must be randomly assigned from the same population
options.D: The homogeneity assumption: individuals within both groups must have identical observable characteristics

questions.question_text: In the Arrow-Debreu model of general equilibrium, what mathematical tool was used to prove that a competitive equilibrium exists across all markets simultaneously?

options.A: The Lagrange multiplier method, optimizing utility subject to budget constraints
options.B: The Kakutani fixed-point theorem, applied to a continuous mapping from a compact convex set into itself
options.C: The minimax theorem from game theory, ensuring optimal strategies in zero-sum markets
options.D: The central limit theorem, showing that aggregate demand converges to a normal distribution

questions.question_text: Arrow's impossibility theorem (1951) is a foundational result in social choice theory. What does the theorem prove about voting systems with three or more alternatives?

options.A: A unique social welfare function exists that maximizes aggregate utility across all possible preference orderings
options.B: All majority-rule systems inevitably produce Pareto-optimal outcomes when voters are fully informed
options.C: Any ranked voting rule will always select the Condorcet winner if one exists among the alternatives
options.D: No ranked voting rule can simultaneously satisfy unrestricted domain, Pareto efficiency, independence of irrelevant alternatives, and non-dictatorship

questions.question_text: Computable general equilibrium (CGE) models use actual economic data to simulate policy impacts across an entire economy. What type of dataset typically forms the backbone of a CGE model?

options.A: A randomized controlled trial dataset with treatment and control firms
options.B: A vector autoregression (VAR) of quarterly GDP components over a twenty-year panel
options.C: A cross-sectional household survey measuring individual consumption preferences
options.D: A social accounting matrix (SAM), which captures all economic transaction flows in the economy for a single year

questions.question_text: The gravity model of trade, first formalized by Jan Tinbergen in 1962, predicts bilateral trade flows between two countries. What are the two primary variables in its traditional specification?

options.A: The population growth rates and the average tariff levels of both countries
options.B: The interest rate differential and the exchange rate volatility between the two countries
options.C: The economic sizes (GDPs) of both countries and the geographic distance between them
options.D: The trade balance deficits and the foreign direct investment stocks of both countries

questions.question_text: James Heckman's two-step correction procedure, for which he shared the 2000 Nobel Prize, addresses a pervasive problem in observational data. What statistical quantity computed from the first-step probit model is inserted into the second-step regression?

options.A: The variance inflation factor, measuring the degree of multicollinearity among regressors
options.B: The Cook's distance statistic, identifying influential outliers that distort coefficient estimates
options.C: The Durbin-Watson statistic, testing for first-order serial correlation in regression residuals
options.D: The inverse Mills ratio, derived from the ratio of the probability density function to the cumulative distribution function of the selection equation's error term

questions.question_text: Alvin Roth and Lloyd Shapley received the 2012 Nobel Prize in Economics for work on stable allocations and market design. What algorithm, originally published by Gale and Shapley in 1962, guarantees a stable matching in two-sided markets?

options.A: The Vickrey-Clarke-Groves auction mechanism, which elicits truthful bids through pivotal payments
options.B: The top trading cycles algorithm, which finds core allocations in one-sided housing markets
options.C: The Hungarian algorithm, which solves the linear assignment problem in polynomial time
options.D: The deferred acceptance algorithm, in which proposers make sequential offers and receivers tentatively hold their best offer

questions.question_text: New institutional economics (NIE), a term coined by Oliver Williamson in 1975, extends neoclassical economics by analyzing the role of institutions. Which concept, central to Ronald Coase's 1937 paper 'The Nature of the Firm,' explains why firms emerge as an alternative to market exchange?

options.A: Comparative advantage, the ability of firms to produce goods at lower opportunity cost than competitors
options.B: Transaction costs, the expenses of negotiating, monitoring, and enforcing contracts that make market exchange costly
options.C: Bounded rationality, the cognitive limitations that prevent agents from processing all available information
options.D: Moral hazard, the tendency of agents to take excessive risks when shielded from consequences

questions.question_text: Regression discontinuity design (RDD), introduced by Thistlethwaite and Campbell in 1960, estimates causal effects by comparing observations near a threshold. What distinguishes a 'fuzzy' RDD from a 'sharp' RDD?

options.A: In fuzzy RDD the running variable is measured with error, while in sharp RDD it is perfectly observed
options.B: In fuzzy RDD the treatment effect varies across subgroups, while in sharp RDD it is constant
options.C: In fuzzy RDD, treatment probability changes discontinuously at the cutoff but does not jump from zero to one, unlike deterministic sharp RDD
options.D: In fuzzy RDD the bandwidth is chosen by cross-validation, while in sharp RDD it is predetermined

questions.question_text: The capability approach, developed by Amartya Sen in the 1980s, offers an alternative framework for evaluating human welfare. What does it assess instead of income or utility?

options.A: Individuals' revealed preferences as inferred from observed consumer spending patterns
options.B: A nation's aggregate GDP per capita adjusted for purchasing power parity across countries
options.C: The Pareto efficiency of resource allocations measured by deadweight loss in competitive markets
options.D: People's substantive freedoms (capabilities) to achieve valued functionings such as being healthy, educated, and socially engaged

questions.question_text: Optimal tax theory studies how to design taxes that maximize social welfare subject to constraints. Frank Ramsey's 1927 rule for commodity taxation states that tax rates should be set so that what condition holds across all taxed goods?

options.A: Tax rates should be proportional to each good's share of total consumer expenditure to maximize revenue
options.B: Tax rates should be inversely proportional to the price elasticities of supply and demand, so less elastic goods are taxed more heavily
options.C: Tax rates should be equal across all goods to minimize administrative costs and avoid market distortions
options.D: Tax rates should be set so that the marginal utility of consumption is equalized across all goods

questions.question_text: The synthetic control method, developed by Alberto Abadie and coauthors, estimates causal effects of large-scale interventions. How does the method construct its counterfactual for the treated unit?

options.A: By running a randomized experiment that assigns the intervention to a randomly selected subset of similar units
options.B: By fitting a structural vector autoregression to the treated unit's time series and forecasting the post-intervention path
options.C: By selecting the single most similar untreated unit based on propensity score matching on observable covariates
options.D: As a data-driven weighted average of untreated units from a donor pool, chosen to match the treated unit's pre-intervention trajectory

questions.question_text: Leonid Hurwicz, Eric Maskin, and Roger Myerson shared the 2007 Nobel Prize for founding mechanism design theory. What does the revelation principle, a central result in this field, establish?

options.A: That the socially optimal outcome is always achieved when agents can freely bargain without transaction costs
options.B: That any outcome achievable by any mechanism can also be achieved by an incentive-compatible direct mechanism in which agents truthfully report their private information
options.C: That every Nash equilibrium of a game is also a dominant-strategy equilibrium when players have complete information
options.D: That all Pareto-efficient allocations can be reached through competitive markets without any government intervention
